title: Sunset on V2: The End of an Era at Starbase
summary: On Monday, October 13th, 2025 at 6:15pm Booster 15-2 and Ship 38 lifted off from Launch Pad 1 at SpaceX’s Starbase, Texas launch facility and closing out the V1/V2 chapter of the Starship program.
detailed_news: Flight 11 was a largely successful test flight for the Starship Program, with Booster and Ship meeting all of their stated pre-flight goals. With its successful splashdown and Boosters successful demonstrations, this flight marks the close of the 2025 Starship campaign. 2026 will introduce the next iteration of Starship and Superheavy, V3, on the completely redesigned launch pad at Tower 2. Pad 1 began stacking in early 2021, eventually being completed later that year. Ship 24 and Booster 7 took flight on the hazy morning of April 20th, 2023 from Pad 1, marking the first full stack flight from the first iteration of the Orbital Launch Mount (OLM) Ship 25 became the first Starship to reach space, though it would not return.  2025 was set to be a key year for the Starship program, but unfortunately SpaceX’s hopes for a high flight rate were met with setback after setback due to the newly introduced V2 ships. The launch of Flight 7 on January 16th, 2025 marked the first launch of the second version of the Starship upper stage. Starbase’s Gigabay is well under way at the location of the original High Bay. The future for Starship remains in flux, with pressure mounting from NASA to have it ready for Artemis III. 2026 is set to be a new era for not only Starbase, but for the Starship program.

detailed_news: Arianespace has confirmed that the first flight of the more powerful, four-booster variant of the Ariane 6 rocket will not be launched until 2026. The first Ariane 64 rocket had been expected to launch in late 2025, carrying the first batch of Amazon’s Project Kuiper satellites.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 28 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg
summary: The Starlink 11-19 mission will be SpaceX’s 50th launch from Vandenberg Space Force Base in 2025. It’s targeting liftoff from pad Space Launch Complex 4 East at 10:59 a.m. PDT (1:59 p.m. EDT / 1759 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is preparing for its 50th Falcon 9 rocket launch from Vandenberg Space Force Base on Sunday. The Starlink 11-19 mission will add another 28 Starlink satellites to its broadband internet constellation in low Earth orbit. There are more than 8,600 satellites currently in orbit, according to stats maintained by astronomer and expert orbital tracker Jonathan McDowell.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch Falcon 9 rocket on record-breaking 31st flight
summary: The Starlink 10-17 mission will add another 28 broadband satellites into low Earth orbit. SpaceX is targeting liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station at 11:49 a.m. EDT (1549 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is set to break another reuse record on Sunday when it launches a Falcon 9 booster for a record-breaking 31st time. The company’s most flown rocket will be used to launch the Starlink 10-17 mission from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station. Liftoff from Space Launch Complex 40 is scheduled for 11:49 a.m. EDT (1549 UTC) The 45th Weather Squadron forecast a greater than 95 percent chance for favorable weather.

detailed_news: ODIN’S EYE project was funded by the European Union under the European Defence Fund. The project aims to develop a sovereign space-based early warning capability that would detect and track the launch of ballistic missiles. In July 2021, an initial €7.5 million was awarded to an OHB System-led consortium.

title: ESA astronauts complete helicopter training in preparation for future lunar missions
summary: Four ESA astronauts have completed a helicopter training course with the German Bundeswehr, Germany’s federal defence forces, marking a key milestone in Europe’s preparations for future missions to the Moon and operations on the lunar surface.
detailed_news: Four ESA astronauts have completed a helicopter training course with the German Bundeswehr. The training is a key milestone in Europe’s preparations for future missions to the Moon and operations on the lunar surface. Helicopter training offers a realistic analogue for the dynamics of planetary landings, requiring capabilities such as vertical take-off and landing.

title: Earth from Space: Chilean glaciers
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: Laguna San Rafael National Park is located on the Pacific coast of southern Chile. It includes the Northern Patagonian Ice Field, a remnant of the Patagonia Ice Sheet. Today, despite the ice field being just a fraction of its previous size, it is still the second largest continuous mass of ice outside the polar regions. The ice mass feeds glaciers that have changed in size between 1987 and 2024.

title: Orion spacecraft arrives at VAB ahead of stacking for Artemis 2
summary: This is the first spacecraft that will carry humans on a mission to the Moon since 1972. The Artemis 2 mission is scheduled for no earlier than Feb. 5, 2026.
detailed_news: Orion spacecraft made its penultimate terrestrial roadtrip late Thursday evening. The spacecraft made the roughly seven-mile journey from the Launch Abort System Facility to the VAB. The trek came almost four years to the day after NASA rolled the Orion spacecraft used on the Artemis 1 mission. The first crewed flight of the Artemis program is set to launch no earlier than Feb. 5 from the Kennedy Space Center. Teams are still working to nail down the specific launch windows available to them in each month. Depending on exactly when they launch, the four-person crew will spend roughly ten days in the confines of the Orion capsule.

title: ESA astronauts complete helicopter training in preparation for future lunar missions
summary: ESA astronauts Alexander Gerst, Matthias Maurer, Samantha Cristoforetti and Thomas Pesquet completed a helicopter training course with the German Bundeswehr, Germany's federal defence forces. They participated in a three-week training programme at the International Helicopter Training Centre in Bückeburg, Germany. The course included  one week of simulator instruction followed by two weeks of practical flying in EC135 helicopters, with operations conducted over central Germany and in mountainous terrain in the German Alps.

title: Phoebus: keeping the smallest molecule in the Universe contained
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: Phoebus is a European Space Agency (ESA) project together with ArianeGroup and MT Aerospace. It aims to assess the feasibility and benefits of replacing the metallic tanks on ESA’s Ariane 6 upper stage with carbon-fibre reinforced-plastic tanks. While this lightweight material offers the possibility of saving several tonnes of mass, such an approach has never been implemented before.

title: Spain celebrates ESA heritage with substantial plans for the future
summary: The European Space Agency's presence in Spain is set to be strengthened, while more than a dozen contracts with Spanish industry were signed on Thursday.
detailed_news: The Agencia Espacial Española (AEE) signed a new letter of intent with ESA. The AEE also joined the zero-debris charter during a day of celebrations of ESA's 50th anniversary at the European Space Astronomy Centre (ESAC) near Madrid. Spain's contribution to ESA has grown by 50% in the last seven years. Nine contracts were signed under ESA’s Navigation Innovation and Support Programme (NAVISP) The activities have a total value of over €10 million, with ESA co-funding half of the budget. The projects were selected from a pool of proposals following a call by ESA and the AEE earlier this year.

title: First bedrest samples arrive at exploration biobank in Portugal
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: ESA's new Exploration Biobank received its first biological samples linked to European space research in Portugal this week. The shipment contained over 1400 human samples from the Vivaldi III bedrest and dry-immersion campaign. The biological repository will remain stored at –80°C in remotely monitored freezers.

title: Once unthinkable, NASA and Lockheed now consider launching Orion on other rockets
summary: "We're trying to crawl, then walk, then run into our reuse strategy."
detailed_news: Orion spacecraft and Space Launch System rocket have been attached at the hip for the better part of two decades. Lockheed Martin has begun to pivot toward a future in which the Orion spacecraft fits into commercial space applications. In interviews, company officials said that if NASA wanted to buy Orion missions as a "service," rather than owning and operating the spacecraft. NASA and Lockheed are working on a plan to reuse components of the Orion spacecraft. The plan calls for a step-by-step approach. Lockheed will never achieve "full and rapid reusability" for Orion like SpaceX is attempting with its Starship vehicle. But Orion is here and ready for its first astronauts in 2026. Ars is a trusted source in a sea of information. You don’t need to know everything, only what’s important. With our unique combination of technical savvy and wide-ranging interest in the technological arts and sciences, we can help you understand the world around you.

title: Isaacman Back in the Running for NASA Administrator
summary: Jared Isaacman is among a group of candidates being interviewed by NASA Acting Administrator Sean Duffy to take the top job at the agency on a permanent basis.  President Trump […]
detailed_news: Jared Isaacman is among a group of candidates being interviewed by NASA Acting Administrator Sean Duffy to take the top job at the agency on a permanent basis. President Trump nominated Isaacman for the position on January 20, but withdrew it at the end of May in a move widely attributed to Trump’s falling out with Elon Musk. NASA confirmed to SpacePolicyOnline.com that Sean Duffy met with Isaacman last week and also is interviewing other candidates. Isaacman, who’s nickname is Rook, has remained above the fray posting on X (@rookisaacman) about his gratitude to the President for nominating him in the first place.

title: Starship Block 2 and Pad 1 end on a high note with Flight 11
summary:
SpaceX completed the use of Block 2 and Pad 1 on a high note with…
The post Starship Block 2 and Pad 1 end on a high note with Flight 11 appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX completed the use of Block 2 and Pad 1 on a high note with a completely successful mission with Flight 11. All 33 engines were running at liftoff, and unlike Flight 10, no engines shut off during the ascent. With the boost back complete, and for the final time, Booster 15-2 separated its hotstage ring to let it fall into the gulf. Super Heavy Booster 15-2 was down-selected from 13 engines to five engines, then down to three. This landing burn profile will enable more redundancy during the final adjustment phase of the landing burn, and allowing the booster to exert greater control over its trajectory. The booster entered a hover above the Gulf before shutting off all its engines, dropping into the water, and exploding. The day after launch, SpaceX released drone footage of the belly flop and landing. Flight 11 was a perfect send-off for Blocks 1 and 2 and for Pad 1 as SpaceX ends flight tests this year on a high note. Next up is Block 3, Raptor 3, and Pad 2(B) with Booster 18 and Ship 39. It is unclear when these vehicles will be ready for single-vehicle testing and eventually full-stack testing.

title: Live coverage: Overnight launch planned for 28 more Starlink satellites
summary: The Starlink 10-52 mission is anticipated to be SpaceX’s 130th Falcon 9 launch of the year. The rocket’s liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station is scheduled for Thursday, Oct. 16, at 5:27 a.m. EDT (0927 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX launched the Starlink 10-52 mission from Space Launch Complex 40 at 5:27 a.m. EDT (0927 UTC) The company used its drone ship, ‘Just Read the Instructions,’ to recover the booster nearly 8.5 minutes after liftoff. This was the 138th landing on this vessel and the 519th booster landing to date.

The post Romania’s INCAS Delivers Space Rider Drop Test Model appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Romania’s National Institute for Aerospace Research ‘Elie Carafoli’ (INCAS) has delivered the Space Rider Descent and Landing Test Model (DLRM) to the Italian Aerospace Research Centre (CIRA) in Capua. CIRA was contracted by Space Rider Re-entry Module prime contractor, Thales Alenia Space, in late 2021 to oversee a series of drop tests.

title: Beyond the downlink: Why Earth-independent AI is the next moat in space operations
summary:
Every new space mission runs into the same wall: physics and fragility. Physics, because the speed of light and contested spectrum make real-time decision-making from the ground impossible when you need it most. Fragility, because modern space systems are software-defined, interconnected, and therefore exposed to radiation-induced faults, cascading anomalies and increasingly sophisticated cyber threats. title: Flying through the biggest solar storm ever recorded
summary: No communication or navigation, faulty electronics and collision risk. At ESA’s mission control in Darmstadt, teams faced a scenario unlike any before: a solar storm of extreme magnitude. Fortunately, this nightmare unfolded not in reality, but as part of the simulation campaign for Sentinel-1D, pushing the boundaries of spacecraft operations and space weather preparedness.
detailed_news: ESA simulation campaign for Sentinel-1D, scheduled for launch on 4 November 2025. The exercise replicated the effects of a catastrophic solar storm on satellite operations to test the team’s ability to respond without satellite navigation and under severe electronic disruption. The simulation team has modelled a massive, X45-class flare, with intense X-ray and ultraviolet radiation disrupting radar systems, communications, and tracking data. An event of such magnitude would severely degrade the quality of conjunction data. Single-event upsets became even more frequent, impairing systems and shortening operational life. GNSS signals degraded further, star trackers went blind and battery charging events added to the chaos. The simulation will provide critical insights for the constitution of European-wide space weather operational services.

title: Beyond Gravity plans US push after fivefold boost in European solar mechanism output
summary:
Beyond Gravity is weighing expanding solar array drive mechanism production in Florida to support Golden Dome and other U.S. space projects, after doubling manufacturing space in Europe for hardware that keeps satellites pointed toward the sun.

title: ESA Exploration Biobank in Portugal Receives First Human Samples
summary:
The European Space Agency’s (ESA) Exploration Biobank in Lisbon, Portugal, has received an initial batch of 1,422 samples, which will be used to validate the facility’s workflow. In July, ESA awarded a €300,000, 24-month contract to Portugal’s Gulbenkian Institute of Molecular Medicine (GIMM) to establish the agency’s Exploration Biobank. The contract was part of an […]
The post ESA Exploration Biobank in Portugal Receives First Human Samples appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: The European Space Agency’s (ESA) Exploration Biobank in Lisbon, Portugal, has received an initial batch of 1,422 samples. The facility will store human samples from space missions and studies investigating the effects of microgravity on the human body. Once the facility is certified, what remains of the 4,380 human samples collected as part of the Vivaldi III study that have not yet been delivered will be transferred.
